reviewText:
Being someone who is terrible at games like FPSes, which seem to make up the majority of people's games these days, I have always been looking for something new. After finding this indie marvel, I am completely ADDICTED to Guns of Icarus Online.

The flawlessly turning cogs, the beautiful sound of steam in highly detailed machinery, the immense feel of achievement from working with a team to control a giant metal airship, and destroying others with the finest weapons from the four corners of the world.
Whether it's a continues stream of hellfire from a long-range flamethrower, the adrenaline-surging Heavy Hwacha with its fast and furious stream of explosives, landing mercilessly on an enemy ship and wrecking it like a hammer against glass, or le surprise buttesecks from a high power sniper cannon, you can be sure of a damn good time for you, and a nightmare for the recipients of your destruction. As long as you're on the winning team, of course. But don't worry about losing too much, because even if you do, your fellow (and rival) captains have the option to give you a 'Commendation' as a mute way of saying 'You did well.' There is a minor levelling system that makes it easy to distinguish the more experienced players from the less experienced, as you level up with the number of class-related achievements you get.

The community in Guns of Icarus Online is mostly a mature, welcoming one that will not only tell you where you went wrong in a match but also recommending improvements and resisting the urge to brag. The developers of Guns of Icarus Online are always online with their unmistakable green name and easy-going attitude, answering as many questions as they can in the relatively easy-going main chat, and occasionally host 'Dev Matches' where you can compete against them for a free in-game customisation item. It is in ways like this they show how they genuinely care about their customers. Something that is unfortunately missing in many modern game studios.

In summary, if you have a passion for all things Steampunk, want a brilliant community with a caring company behind it and enjoy destroying giant metal birds, climb aboard the Icarus and together we'll sail for a brave new world.

reviewText:
if you like steampunk zepplines and fierce battles in the open skys using guns missles and everything in between then this game should be bought now. if you need more convincing this game is UNIQUE I mean it does things differntly and it does them well.
you do everything from a first person perspective including fly the ship which makes the strategy of the game more apperent each ship ahs blind spots for both the pilot and the guns so you can sneak up on people or just slug it out you have to work with people in your crew. their is a lot of customization from your loadout to your ships guns. generaly the game is great the community is nice the batles are intense each person from the newest player to the oldest veteran have a job and the downtime fixing your ship just intensifys the action. finaly te ships are all well designed to add to the fun of play and they arent invincible by any means but they dont die easily you can survive most opening barrages and if you hide fix yourself up to fight again.

now of course this game isnt perfect the ships guns have really odd places they cant hit and the spotting is a bit finicky but this isnt gamebraking by any means i am realy just nitpicking and these problems get less and less each update.  if your still not convinced jsut find a freind who has it and play a few rounds with each class you will love it.

reviewText:
Guns of Icarus is a perfect combination of teamwork and strategy as you try to outmanuvre your opponents and blow them out of the sky.

Graphics are amazing. It is just a pretty game in general.

Teamcomps are a bit stale as the Gunner class brings less to the crew than running 3 engineers and the pilot together. But then it is currently in beta at the time of posting so we will see what they implement here.

However there is a large variety of perks for the classes, such as the lucky foot which increases the turn angle of your ship, as well as different weapon loadouts for the many ships available to use. These include things like mines and flamthrowers amongst the cannon and rocket like guns you would expect.

This game is fun to play and even more fun if you can get a team of four friends to communicate with. alothough you have a voice chat option in game it is alot more difficult communicating to random players than to your friends over a service like mumble or skype.

Overall the game deserves a much higher rating than the one it has been given and i hope to sink many hours into it as they bring out things like the adventure mode building up to the full release.

reviewText:
Guns of Icarus Online... sounds promising, doesn't it? And it pretty much is VERY promising. I mean, I could probably go on and on about how good this game is and how I just adore it, even though I didn't really play that much (seeing as some people have 1k+ hours on this and I have a mere 27+). I'll try to make it as brief of a review as I can but don't blame me if it ends up pretty long (because there's a number of things I wish to describe).
My first thought about this game was 'Oh my, a steampunk game about airships! Now that's a must have!'. I should probably tell you know that I'm a BIG steampunk fan. But back to the topic at hand: when I bought Guns of Icarus Online and actually got into a real game I was stunned. And no it wasn't because it was bad. Two words: airship battles. And not the kind you would expect from a regular multiplayer deathmatch oriented game where you fly a ship and pew pew everything in sight. Instead you get a team effort game. You and three other people are the whole crew of an airship (and you have about seven to choose from). You man the guns, keep the blasted thing alive and shoot other airships. Each member of your glorious crew is of one of the following professions: captain (responsible for flying the ship), engineer (repairs and rebuilds the ship parts) or gunner (your pew pew man). Of course, there some multi-classing aspects and everyone can attend to other jobs (only not so well).
Doesn't sound impressive? Well then, let me assure you that those combats are gloriously dynamic. You run around whacking things with a rubber mallet, shoot things or manoeuvre through the skies, hoping you don't get sandwiched by two Galleons and you can actually FEEL that you're a part of the crew. And it's not that you carry" people to victory. It's completely about the effort of everyone on the ship. I don't know about others but those kind of feels really get to me.
And speaking of airships
date: they are designed so very well. They have this steampunk touch I so love about them. And not only that they look really well they also come in a decent variety. On one side of the list you have a big
recommended: slow airship packed with tons of heavy weaponry. On the other there's a fast
hoursPlayed: mobile ship with no heavy guns (though has an annoying tendency to burn you all the time). Maybe something in between? Though there's only seven ships
voteText: I'm sure most people will find something that suits them (my two personal favourites are the Spire and the Mobula). The only downside I can see here is that some of the ships are the engineer's worst nightmares (ironic that my favourites are those nightmares... and I play the engineer).\nNow let's speed this review up a bit. The graphics are nice. I really like the particles and how the ships look. So that's a plus. And the music is really good. The voice chat is pretty handy and helps a lot. Alas
helpfulPercent: the game has a few flaws. The first one is that it tends to lag from time to time for no big reason (which isn't really that frustrating... I
votesHelpful: for one
votesTotal: don't really mind) so you end up falling off through the floor of your ship or see a teleporting enemy
votesFunny: and the part you were so eagerly smashing with your mallet isn't very responsive. The second one that comes into my minds is that... it's hard to find games and crew. Don't get me wrong
commentsCount: there's quite a lot of people playing this game but it just doesn't seem enough. Mornings and early afternoons are simply underpopulated (I know
column16: people have lives... but what are the odds?). I know it's not really a technical flaw
column17:
but it kind of gets me down. And lastly I... don't really have any major flaws to report.
And I must say that the developers are fantastic. So is the community. I don't think I've ever seen such a friendly community in any online game.

So... that was a tad longer than I intended it to be. No matter. To sum things up: Guns of Icarus Online is a very good online game. It's a perfect buy for any steampunk fan out there who would like to actually participate in an airship battle and feel like a real sky pirate (or maybe not really a pirate but you get the point). And when you get friends to man your ship? Now that's the best thing you can do with your free time. I recommend this game to everyone

column19: this is a pretty darn good multiplayer team effort game. So go buy it. We need more pilots

reviewText:
THE SHORT REVIEW:
A fun co-operative game to enjoy with friends, highly recomend the four pack if you do decide to pick this game up.

THE LONG REVIEW:
This game is quite literally co-operative, you will need to have someone doing their jobs or you and your teammates are screwed. Why did I recomend the four pack? It's best to play GoI with people you know or at least people who will put the co-op in co-operation cause if you don't then it will be difficult to coordinate different strategies. Not working together will and can get you killed, and not actually following through with the role of your class will warrant the same result.

Guns of Icarus is a neat little game that caught me by suprise because I wasn't expecting it to, well, be fun at all. However the odd matches where friends weren't available to play the game got kind of boring, and it is definetly one of those games where you should atleast have people you know working with you (even though there is a chatbox and such).

MADE FOR: Fans of Steampunk and Flying Ships. It's also made for those who actually have a group to play and communicate with.

NOT MADE FOR: People that dislike games that run on Unity, and of course the whole setting of Steampunk. It's also worth noting that the game really isn't good if you have no one you know to play it with.


GUNS OF ICARUS
7.5/10

reviewText:
Probably one the best games that I have ever played. And I'm not putting that lightly.

Pros:
+ Decent graphics

+ Cool idea

+ Good class balance

+ No pay to win (only cosmetics)

+ Loads of teamwork involved

+ Lots of awesome artwork/designs for ships and clothing

+ Matchmaking is good

+ Not too bad of a price

+ Gets really intense and can leave you feeling like you actually were there, fighting alongside your friends

+ Tutorial is easy and explanatory

+ Tons and tons and tons of customization. Literally anything you could think of

Cons:
- Not well optimised. With my mid-high end custom-built desktop, I run at a solid 60fps until I get into a fight with explosions of any kind, which can sometimes drop my frames to a mere 20-30fps

- Not all the ships are perfectly balanced. There aren't any ships that are overpowered, though some of the ships are never used simply because they aren't as balanced as the others

- Leveling up doesn't have that many rewards

- Not a lot of maps, though you rarely notice your surroundings unless you're a pilot or there's no fighting going on


Other Ideas:
~ If you are playing with a group of 4 friends, this game is, well, simply awesome. However, if you find yourself with any less than 4 of your friends, you can sometimes end up with a newbie crewmate

~ The game doesn't REQUIRE a microphone, though it seems nearly pointless without one. Without the ability to communicate with your crew/party with live voice chat, trying to say things like THE BALLOON IS ON FIRE" can only be said with the (somewhat hard to navigate) built-in voice chat (think TF2 voice commands)"

reviewText:
Guns of Icarus Online is a multiplayer team-based shooter/flight sim/makeshift percussion instrument simulator sequel to the original Guns of Icarus by Muse games. All set in a quirky alternate history where World War I apparently started early and dragged out until humanity was left in a post-apocalyptic state where airships are the way to go because Mad Max makes land travel too lethal.

You are one of three classes, pilot (only one per-ship, directs the ship), engineer (repairs stuff), and gunner (controls the gun mounts) in a group of four (guess which class gets doubled up?) and while each class can man the guns, pilot the ship, and even do some repairs, the classes have customizable loadouts in different categories. Your class gets four tools in their chosen category and only one tool in any other. You and the rest of your crew must function as a tight knit, well-coordinated unit as pilots must keep the ship positioned to fire on enemies, gunners must have an aim worth squat, and engineers need to stay on top of incoming damage to different parts of the ship. Thankfully, unlike the original Guns of Icarus, you no longer have to worry about cargo, just your teammates (including those on other, friendly ships) being subpar to the team members on the opposite team.

What ensues is a game requiring multi-person coordination, open communication, a careful system of checks and balances in terms of equipment loadout, ship class, and armaments in perhaps a great game of teamwork and strategy I myself have never experienced before. Some things you'll need to full enjoy this game will easily be friends to form a crew with (and expendable when the inevitable lost match causes a falling out) or patience, willingness, and possible divine favor to endure the randomized matchmaking, and lastly a good quality mic for communicating with your team or chewing out the other engineer who keeps repairing something you're already fixing when something else needs him more.

But by no means let these words discourage you, indeed, sometimes the frustration can be part of the fun and makes the times when you and your team hit the zone or you end up with just good teammates a zen-like experience of being awesome as the crew of the Enterprise, deftly taking down superior forces of Klingon warships except with more cogs and petrol fumes.

If PVP isn't your thing, the developers have been working on a PvE adventure mode for some time now and progress is apparently steady. Adventure mode will include not just AI controlled enemies, but also towns which you can visit with your avatar character to show off those fancy duds you bought in the cash store, role play your way through your lack of actual skills related to your class, or simply argue your ship is better than everyone elses/complain how broken flamethrowers are.

Oh, did I mention you can not just customize your avatar but also your ship to an extent aesthetically? Well you can, it costs real money but distinguishing yourself is always nice.

Perhaps the current downside is that mechanical options are limited, There's maybe eight different tools to select from for each class, only so many ships, and only so many ways you can load them up in terms of weapons. Things get more restrictive when it comes to the metagame as while the engineers are always important, you end up doing a lot less exciting things and can spend whole matches staring at ship components and smashing them with a tool for repairs or putting out fires because the one gunner and one pilot slot were taken by someone else (and begrudgingly, probably more deserving of those slots than you).

All in all, I highly recommend this game to people, if only to support indie development, and to promote strategic, teamwork dependent multiplayer games. Nevermind hope for future growth and perhaps a broader meta.

reviewText:
I should begin by saying that a fully fledged PvE mode is in the works, though there is no ETA of when it will be done.

This game is a bit of something most people always wanted to have, but never did. If you played the final fantasy games as a kid, like I did, then you probably wondered what a full on battle with your airship would be like.
Guns of Icarus neatly fulfills that by combining slick killer airships, steampunk glory, and the dear old dreams of flight. It's you and three other players, who must steer the airship itself, fire the weapons to take down the enemy, and keep the ship repaired at all times.
Pilot, gunner, and engineer - not a toughie to figure out who does what. While it's worth noting that any role can do anything, pilots gets more items to enhance the performance of the ship itself (at the expense of slowly damaging the systems), gunners get more ammo types, and engineers have more tools to fix the ship.

Decking out your ship is where the real depth lies. There are a lot of weapons at this stage of the game, and knowing what to have when, and at what place of the ship, and with what ammo, is the key to victory. You could be a sniping minelayer, a harpoon'ing flamerboat, or a pure on rocket speedster. There's a lot of combinations, and you will still be learning new ones hundreds of games later. The ships are as varied as the weapons, offering multiple roles per ship depending on what guns and ammo you use. Playing into all of this are the items the pilot is using, be it moonshine to make the engines go faster, kerosense to make the balloon better, or phoenix claw to turn faster - it all comes down to making up for the various ships inate weaknesses.

But, as previously mentioned, that comes at the cost of constantly damaging the affected sub-systems, so pilots needs to take care of that.
See, damage to systems makes them less effective - an engine that's barely alive won't perform anywhere near a full repaired one, and the same goes for everything else. It's all a matter of making priorities under fire, which makes every game intense but rewarding. And because every part of the ship has it's own health, a lot of tactical precision fire comes into play. Aim is important.

The scenery is beautiful - I sometimes forget to do my job as an engineer because I get distracted by all the effects and cool visuals around me. No other game did that to me. It's that good to look at. It's not just scenery though, things like hiding in clouds is definetly a thing. The soundtrack is great, it's subtle but powerful, and often you won't notice it there - you will just suddenly realize how well it sets the mood, and you will quickly learn to fear the sound of hwacha rockets whistling through the air.

But should the soundtrack dissapoint, your teammates can of course play their own over the mic - or whatever else they want to share. Guns of Icarus is extremely voice driven - you simply don't have the time to type under fire. Luckily, it's functional and simple. And better get used to it, because there will be a lot of banter going on in the ship. And that's what makes me adore this game so much, more than anything - people work very closely together to achive a common goal. That makes getting along so extremely important - if you don't have a good chemistry with your crew, then you simply won't do really well. Even in the pre-match lobbies, I often find myself heartily laughing at all the jokes, singing, stories, and general merry banter. It's sorta like a pre-match party!
So yes, if you don't like social games, then this game is not optimized for you. But the community is incredibly inviting and nice!

BUT, if you like airships, epic dogfights, flying in pretty landscapes, and just having a grand old gamer time with people from all over the world, duking it up high above the ground in all it's steampunk glory, and feeling the gratification of achieving success as a team, then this game is impossible to pass up. It's pretty much the only one of it's kind, and it's only getting better. The developer team constantly plays games with the players, so they're never out of touch or lack common insight.

I hope to see you in the skies!

PS: Two advices...
Don't opt out of novice.
Don't fly a galleon if you're not experienced.

reviewText:
One of the best of competitive multiplayer genre and at the same time most underrated game I know. If you're one of those types who always wanted to feel like, let's say, Admiral Horatio Nelson and sail their own ship (or fly, in this case), or command a fleet, THIS GAME WAS MADE FOR YOU.

The gameplay promotes teamwork among the crewmates and the other pilots of your team. The team tactics are interesting aspect of the game. There are numerous ships, tools, weapons and ammunition, each useful in different kind of situations. The combat itself: Long-range, close-range, ramming, stomping etc. - all in three-dimensions and that's awesome.

The most you can get out of this game is if you play with friends and form a crew or a fleet, but if your peers prefer different genres like mine, it's still a great game to play as pilot solo.

Absolutely recommend!

reviewText:
Being someone who is terrible at games like FPSes, which seem to make up the majority of people's games these days, I have always been looking for something new. After finding this indie marvel, I am completely ADDICTED to Guns of Icarus Online.

The flawlessly turning cogs, the beautiful sound of steam in highly detailed machinery, the immense feel of achievement from working with a team to control a giant metal airship, and destroying others with the finest weapons from the four corners of the world.
Whether it's a continues stream of hellfire from a long-range flamethrower, the adrenaline-surging Heavy Hwacha with its fast and furious stream of explosives, landing mercilessly on an enemy ship and wrecking it like a hammer against glass, or le surprise buttesecks from a high power sniper cannon, you can be sure of a damn good time for you, and a nightmare for the recipients of your destruction. As long as you're on the winning team, of course. But don't worry about losing too much, because even if you do, your fellow (and rival) captains have the option to give you a 'Commendation' as a mute way of saying 'You did well.' There is a minor levelling system that makes it easy to distinguish the more experienced players from the less experienced, as you level up with the number of class-related achievements you get.

The community in Guns of Icarus Online is mostly a mature, welcoming one that will not only tell you where you went wrong in a match but also recommending improvements and resisting the urge to brag. The developers of Guns of Icarus Online are always online with their unmistakable green name and easy-going attitude, answering as many questions as they can in the relatively easy-going main chat, and occasionally host 'Dev Matches' where you can compete against them for a free in-game customisation item. It is in ways like this they show how they genuinely care about their customers. Something that is unfortunately missing in many modern game studios.

In summary, if you have a passion for all things Steampunk, want a brilliant community with a caring company behind it and enjoy destroying giant metal birds, climb aboard the Icarus and together we'll sail for a brave new world.

reviewText:
Guns of Icarus is a perfect combination of teamwork and strategy as you try to outmanuvre your opponents and blow them out of the sky.

Graphics are amazing. It is just a pretty game in general.

Teamcomps are a bit stale as the Gunner class brings less to the crew than running 3 engineers and the pilot together. But then it is currently in beta at the time of posting so we will see what they implement here.

However there is a large variety of perks for the classes, such as the lucky foot which increases the turn angle of your ship, as well as different weapon loadouts for the many ships available to use. These include things like mines and flamthrowers amongst the cannon and rocket like guns you would expect.

This game is fun to play and even more fun if you can get a team of four friends to communicate with. alothough you have a voice chat option in game it is alot more difficult communicating to random players than to your friends over a service like mumble or skype.

Overall the game deserves a much higher rating than the one it has been given and i hope to sink many hours into it as they bring out things like the adventure mode building up to the full release.

reviewText:
Guns of Icarus Online is a multiplayer team-based shooter/flight sim/makeshift percussion instrument simulator sequel to the original Guns of Icarus by Muse games. All set in a quirky alternate history where World War I apparently started early and dragged out until humanity was left in a post-apocalyptic state where airships are the way to go because Mad Max makes land travel too lethal.

You are one of three classes, pilot (only one per-ship, directs the ship), engineer (repairs stuff), and gunner (controls the gun mounts) in a group of four (guess which class gets doubled up?) and while each class can man the guns, pilot the ship, and even do some repairs, the classes have customizable loadouts in different categories. Your class gets four tools in their chosen category and only one tool in any other. You and the rest of your crew must function as a tight knit, well-coordinated unit as pilots must keep the ship positioned to fire on enemies, gunners must have an aim worth squat, and engineers need to stay on top of incoming damage to different parts of the ship. Thankfully, unlike the original Guns of Icarus, you no longer have to worry about cargo, just your teammates (including those on other, friendly ships) being subpar to the team members on the opposite team.

What ensues is a game requiring multi-person coordination, open communication, a careful system of checks and balances in terms of equipment loadout, ship class, and armaments in perhaps a great game of teamwork and strategy I myself have never experienced before. Some things you'll need to full enjoy this game will easily be friends to form a crew with (and expendable when the inevitable lost match causes a falling out) or patience, willingness, and possible divine favor to endure the randomized matchmaking, and lastly a good quality mic for communicating with your team or chewing out the other engineer who keeps repairing something you're already fixing when something else needs him more.

But by no means let these words discourage you, indeed, sometimes the frustration can be part of the fun and makes the times when you and your team hit the zone or you end up with just good teammates a zen-like experience of being awesome as the crew of the Enterprise, deftly taking down superior forces of Klingon warships except with more cogs and petrol fumes.

If PVP isn't your thing, the developers have been working on a PvE adventure mode for some time now and progress is apparently steady. Adventure mode will include not just AI controlled enemies, but also towns which you can visit with your avatar character to show off those fancy duds you bought in the cash store, role play your way through your lack of actual skills related to your class, or simply argue your ship is better than everyone elses/complain how broken flamethrowers are.

Oh, did I mention you can not just customize your avatar but also your ship to an extent aesthetically? Well you can, it costs real money but distinguishing yourself is always nice.

Perhaps the current downside is that mechanical options are limited, There's maybe eight different tools to select from for each class, only so many ships, and only so many ways you can load them up in terms of weapons. Things get more restrictive when it comes to the metagame as while the engineers are always important, you end up doing a lot less exciting things and can spend whole matches staring at ship components and smashing them with a tool for repairs or putting out fires because the one gunner and one pilot slot were taken by someone else (and begrudgingly, probably more deserving of those slots than you).

All in all, I highly recommend this game to people, if only to support indie development, and to promote strategic, teamwork dependent multiplayer games. Nevermind hope for future growth and perhaps a broader meta.

reviewText:
One of the best of competitive multiplayer genre and at the same time most underrated game I know. If you're one of those types who always wanted to feel like, let's say, Admiral Horatio Nelson and sail their own ship (or fly, in this case), or command a fleet, THIS GAME WAS MADE FOR YOU.

The gameplay promotes teamwork among the crewmates and the other pilots of your team. The team tactics are interesting aspect of the game. There are numerous ships, tools, weapons and ammunition, each useful in different kind of situations. The combat itself: Long-range, close-range, ramming, stomping etc. - all in three-dimensions and that's awesome.

The most you can get out of this game is if you play with friends and form a crew or a fleet, but if your peers prefer different genres like mine, it's still a great game to play as pilot solo.

Absolutely recommend!

reviewText:
Guns of Icarus Online is a steampunk airship combat game. As a pilot, I choose and customise an airship (you get all the airships when you buy the game, no airship DLC nonsense) and either wait for a crew or invite some friends. There can be up to three crew members, and if nobody shows up then AIs do the job (badly, of course, since they're hard to communicate with).

Crew members will be one of two chosen classes: gunner or engineer. Gunners man the guns, engineers repair - in theory. Anyone can man a gun, and engineers often will do so when nothing needs repairing.

And now to what I actually think. It's a fun game, with great aesthetics - when I go to ram an airship (and I always end up ramming), I can see the crew of the other ship. They're so tiny. They look like little ants. I like ants. Have you ever seen a close-up picture of an ant? Yeah, ants are cool. Ant-Man had some pet ants, I think. He could shrink, too.

*Ahem* Anyway. Your character is customiseable, though most stuff requires you to buy (or design!) items from the store. So either your crew or ships that are really really close will see it.

There's a few issues, though - many people seem to be unable to refrain from naming their ship something ridiculous, like Yoda's Virginity". I had to give orders to my crew like "Quick
date: after The Yoda's Virginity!" or "Destroy Yoda's Virginity!". I felt quite silly.\n\nAlso
recommended: my ship is haunted. An AI keeps appearing and just charging right off the side and vanishing. It's a funny glitch.\n\nIn conclusion
hoursPlayed: it's a steampunk game about airships and the airships explode with fireworks when they die. You should buy it if you like airships

reviewText:
This is one of THE best co-op games ever created.
For one, it has basically created a whole new genre and it also has a clear concept in mind, and does not get diverted from its goal. Most games that are co-op are basically single player games that you can play with your friends (i. e. Diablo), but this game really makes or brakes depending on your teamwork.
It is crucial that everyone on your ship knows their job and function. Flying solo is a no go.
The one thing this game lacks, is the audience it deserves. This game should get the proper attention from media and gamers alike. We need more people maning our ships, to spread chaos across the skies.

Can't wait for adventure mode
12/10 in my opinion!

reviewText:
An arid wind brushes your face as you walk on the wooden decks. You take the last swig of your liquer before you look over the deck of the ship. Below you is a vast desert, an obvious excuse why you are flying over instead of traveling through. You watch as a rusted out battle ship, one of the many scars of the great war centuries ago, slowly passes by under you in the sand. You throw your empty bottle off the ship and watch it dissapear as it falls to earth.

reviewText:
I recently bought this and I have played around 10 matches so far so let me specify on why this game is WORTH EVERY CENT !

Basically, you are in a 4-man crew with 3 class types (Commander, Gunner and Engineer) and the game is balanced around its variety and massive battles which may range from 30 seconds to 5-minute long positioning and precise syncing the guns.

The players are the ones who deliver the experience.
Even if you are a lone wolf with no party or friends to accompany you in this Steampunk adventure, the players seem fond of teamwork and they will often communicate via to voice chat and listen to you back as well. Coordination is key in this game and the teamwork adds a new dimension to this game.

Customization and balancing :
Basically... you have everything unlocked from start and you can customize a variety of preset ships to your likings ranging from which guns to put where to what kind of gun you want : A tank with heavy weapons that is slow or a speeder with lower health and small guns. Having everything in ship customization unlocked right off the bat is the perfect way to fix anyone's whining of how the game lacks balance. The rest of the customization is just for looks and it adds nothing... + they're cheap anyway.

Last but not least : Future updates..
Adventure mode which is pretty much gonna add an MMO-like mode in the skirmish-like battles in this game will be something like you experienced in EVE only first person and there will be towns, economy, free-roaming and so much more to look for.

Bottom point - GOTY material from every angle.. I can only wish for people to buy this game and maybe if its price stayed at 10 euro for a while it could gain some fame but again, the devs do need to get some money for the masterpiece they've created. The only flaw I can find in this game is when we are playing on a 2v2 match and the enemies are dumb and don't know what the M key does (aka opens the map so we don't have to follow them outside of the boundaries).

If I could give this game a score, I'd give it a 9/10 now and a 10/10 when the Adventure mode releases. Incredibly addicting and so much customization with no balancing issues.. I can only say Buy this and get a 4-pack if you can so you spread the word". Best 20 euro I've ever spent on a game and my friends are in love with it too (I even got 8 more people to buy the game so we have 3 crews for 3v3.. they are that hyped about it too).

People.. the new juggernaut has come but give it time to rise among the leaders of today's gaming. This combination of FPS and piloting is creative
date: fun and most of all - Perfect !"

reviewText:
This is, in my opinion, one of those one of a kind" games that i fall in love with. Where elese will you find a game where you can steer a steampunk stylised flying ship against others with actual human beings as your crew? This game got me right on since the very begining.

I've been playing this game alot and what I like the most here is :

-The maps which are perfectly accostumed for flying and manuvering ranging from more open ones to extremaly narrow ones like cities. They also feel like they belong to the world of the game which is important to me as not every game does it.

-The co-operation which is crucial for this game make other players actully care for the communication and coordination  since this is one of those game that you absolutely have no chance playing solo and not listening to your teammates
date: especailly captain of the ship.\n\n-The theme is also a great attribute to this game. I think steampunk setting of the world fits perfectly here making all the ships
hoursPlayed:
all the guns and its animations and character costumes alot more enjoyable

-The buisness model is very fair as the only things you can buy in shop are customisation items with pretty affordable prices I would say (if you can farm up some trading cards on steam you will even be able to buy a couple of those!).

-Everything is unlocked from the very beginging
voteText: you do not need to through any mundune process of gradually gaining a new item once every couple of levels. Every ship
helpfulPercent: every gun
votesHelpful: every tool or ammunition type is avail for all classes since the very beginging. While this might be kind of overwhelming for newcomers I can guarantee you that you will get a hang of it fairly early on.\n\n-The community here more often then so is in my opinion surprisingly helpful (yes you can find your standard ♥♥♥♥♥♥s who will be mad at anyone who screws up even a bit but they are in minority here). I've met alot of players who can call themsleves veterans and they were always willing to explain what should I do
votesTotal:
how to act on a certains ships and set ups or what is the best combination of tools/ammunition I can take with me.

This game for the majority of time was and still is alot of fun and competetiveness for me.
If anything the only thing to put here and cons would probably be:

-While being great the community is rather small for this game so I can't guarantee if this game will survive although it has been sustaining itself for quiet a long time and does a good job of it. Nevertheless I felt like it should have been signalised

-Ignore this point if you do not care for achievements on steam. this game has a reallygood deal of achievements on steam making this a really long and grindy road to 100%. The other side of these here is that some of those will be especially hard to get as some of the achievements refer to new players giving you a recommendation and vice-versa. This would not actually be such a big problem if the community was bigger but as of now there is alot more old veteran players than the new ones.

Overall I think the game is great and I strongly recommend others to try tis one out. Especially if you have a group of friends who would be willing to fly with you. The 4-pack deal is pretty great as you save up 20 euro that way making the game essentially 50% cheaper without a discount!
I will say this if you like flying ships and raining down death on enemies you won't regret buying this game!"

reviewText: Guns of Icarus is a game that focuses heavily on cooperation and teamwork. You and 3 friends (or complete strangers) fly on an airship trying to destroy the enemy ships before they destroy you. In order to do that, you have to work together and communicate with your team, you can't do it on your own. This has resulted in best online community I've experienced so far. The game does have a learning curve, but it is not as steep as other competitive games, and the community loves to help those who show interest in learning the ways of the game.\n\nSo if you are looking for a game where you can have a nice chat with other players and work together to achieve a goal, or just like competitive games, but want to avoid the toxicity you find in many other games, give Guns of Icarus a try!

reviewText: This, like many other titles, is MUCH better with friends. Howver, if you are a lonely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, not to worry, plenty of people will communicate over the mic with you. reviewText: It's a really good co-op deathmatch experience involving a very high level of teamwork (for example, the pilot has to be in communication with the gunners so the ship is perfectly aligned for shooting, and engineers have to repair the most essential portions of the ship to avoid destruction). The game itself allows for seamless communication, and the graphics are appreciable. All in all, it's highly recommended; but I'm not too serious with this game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is great! It is kind of like a real-time version of FTL with movement, in which you control an individual crew member. The roles are all fun to play and each one is important to your crew as a whole. The gameplay is great, requiring a decent amount of planning and multitasking ability to master, and players can develop their own unique styles of play which keeps the game very replayable.

I do wish that there were more ships and maps though, but the ones that do exist are great. Each map is made in a pretty unique way which emphasizes certain mechanics, and each ship has a niche to fill on the playing field which still allows for plenty of creativity.

The overall polish of the game is decent - it's a bit buggy in some places and the graphics are not AAA quality, but the gameplay makes up for it completely.

reviewText: With a good team, this game is an insane amount of fun. Teamwork is key; If you and your team don't work together expect to die over and over again. If you're a captain, talk with your crew. If you hit the moonshine and start wrecking the engines, tell the engineers so they can account for it. In the pre-game lobby, tell your gunner (or engineers if you're on a hard-to-repair ship, bringing 3 engi's works wonders) of a certain ammo type you like to have loaded in certain guns.

reviewText:
Can't really say much that nobody else has already said. I can give you some advice I've discovered from playing around.

No matter what class you plan to stick with the most, try them all out no matter what. Usually, it gives you a taste of what your teammates have to go through.

My example is this: I usually play as Pilot. However, wanting to change things up a bit, I occasionally played and Engineer and Gunner, to get a taste of what they're like. When I played as these classes, I learned first hand how frustrating it can be for an Engineer when your Pilot flies you into a storm or forgets to stop using an item, and how a Gunner is useless if the Pilot doesn't aim the ship in a manner that allows you to attack. Now, I do my best as a Pilot to ensure things stay in perfect condition so that the Engineers can help gun, and I always try to aim the ship so that the Gunner's don't have to deal with being unable to aim and shoot.

TL:DR, Literally put yourself into your teammates' shoes. It'll help you get better at whatever class you favor and help them to help you.

EDIT: One more thing. Engineers and Gunners should learn the basics of Piloting. That way, if you get a Pilot who leaves the game and strands your ship, you still have someone who can drive it so that you still have some chance. And beginner Pilots: if things are going rough in a match, don't just abandon your team because it's hard. Engineers and Gunners can be replaced with AIs. AIs can't Pilot.

reviewText:
I personally think this game is great. I have some issues with it, but on the whole I think it is good. The needed coordination among teammates is essential, and I think what really makes this game is what they DIDN'T add. Lack of boarding, and hand-to-hand combat really emphasize teamwork, and if you don't have a good team, you are screwed.

Some of the things I dislike are mostly minor, and I think will be fixed with time. The graphics are good, but on certain maps, (i.e. any with rain, or fog) I feel like it was poorly done. Also, the lack of game modes begins to get to you after a while, but they are working on adventure mode, the DLC for which i will definitely buy. On the whole, I would give it a 7/10, and I would love to give it more, but it is not the kind of game you could lose yourself in.

I built up a ton of expectation about this one, and while unrealistic, it feels slightly like a letdown. But it will get better, and what they have now is impressive. Good work guys.

Guns Of Icarus Online is one of the best games i have played in hole my life.

Why?

Good graphics. AWESOME gameplay. FANTASTIC community and developers

reviewText:
Really funny and good teamwork game
(First in English, Spanish below) (Primero en ingles, en Español debajo).

ENGLISH | INGLES

I have played it for more than 30 hours and I'm sure it will increase every day.

I will try to be simple with this review so I will resume my thoughts about it (this is just my personal opinion):

PROS:
Easy controls.
Customizable ships and characters.
When you sink another ship with a good teamwork, it's really a good moment.
Can play as 3 different roles.
Be a pilot with a good crew feeling that anyone can beat your ship.
CONS:
Graphics aren't so good.
Need some time to learn to use the guns properly.
Bad teamwork can be really annoying (but in my case, It has been only a few times).
Sometimes you have to wait to join an available room.
P.S.: I'm sorry for my english, I tried to do my best.

ESPAÑOL | SPANISH

He jugado mas de 30 horas y seguro que va a aumentar cada dia.

Intentaré ser simple con el análisis asi que voy a resumir mis pensamientos sobre el juego (Esto es solo mi opinión personal):

PROS:
Controles faciiles.
Naves y personajes personalizables.
Cuando hundes otra nave con un buen juego de equipo, es de verdad un gustazo.
Poder jugar como 3 roles distintos.
Ser piloto con una buena tripulación haciendote sentir que nadie puede con tu nave.
CONS:
Los gráficos no son del todo buenos.
Se requiere tiempo para aprender a usar las armas apropiadamente.
El mal juego en equipo puede hacerte enfadar mucho (pero en mi caso esto solo ha pasado un par de veces).
A veces hay que esperar un rato hasta poder unirte a alguna sala disponible.

reviewText: Incredibly fun game. Airship combat featuring 2v2, 3v3 and 4v4 team based gamemodes of Deathmatch and King of The Hill. Frequented by community ambassadors who will teach people anything they need to know, this game is easy to learn but hard to master. Always being updated with new content and bug fixes, and the devs are very active within the player base as well. There are ALWAYS people playing this, so it doesn't matter where you live, you can always find a game to jump into. Most people have microphones too, so don't be afraid to engage in some crew banter to make everyone's jobs easier.\n\nIf you love being involved in quality teamwork where every person makes a difference, consider picking this game up and playing with your close friends or make some new friends to regularly experience the joy of blowing someone else's ship up. Join a clan or fly solo, make a name for yourself, and become the most feared airman of the skies!

Guns of Icarus is an excellent Steampunk Airship tactical.

reviewText: This game is a steampunk version of pirates of the carribean, as you steer a sub-par ship agaisnt other ships, the game works well alone, and you'll have a hard time being on your own, which is why the game requires that you assemble a team of 4 for your ship, you can rather have these people be your friends, or some random dudes who don't know what they're doing. The Ship mechanic is fresh, with instead holding down W or S or pushing up or down on the joystick, you have a speed toggle, so you lock the speed to 5 speeds, very fast reverse, reverse, stop, fast, very fast forward. My only problems so far is that sometimes your ship gets randomly thrown into mountains and hills, making you take damage for nothing. though this is only happened to me once. Apart from that this game is very fun and made me laugh alot. This game IS for friends so I recommend you buy the four pack.

reviewText:
This game is just Medidicci Genius. It saved my life. (Kappa). (Fade Out).
(Fade In).
It was October 5th, 1901, and I had just gotten my sonic screwdriver from the Doctor Who Warehouse sale. Of course, I was rich, being able to afford such a magnificent item. It had costed me a whole 90 cents. Compared to today, that was around a whopping 100,000 zen.
I was rolling down the streets, and the total gangsta's in the alley were hatin' me. Ya feel?
So anyway, I approached the bus stop, and with each step, I felt the growing presence of the gangsta's who were beginning to swarm around me.
I should've looked back.
(Fade out).
Dramatic Pause. (Que the screaming noise).
(Fade in).
I awoke, thirsty, hungry, and most importantly, noticed that someone had taken my first edition Sonic Screwdriver that I had gotten.
I was chained up to the walls of what looked to be like someone's garage. I had little hope. No phone, no food, no water, and no screwdriver.
I spent over a month there. By that time I had begun eating my left foot, and drank the blood that spewed out of it.
Occasionally, a man dressed in all black came to give me some chicken scraps.
I ate the bones.
They kept me slave and I had worked for them for 3 months more. I was almost dead.
(Fade out).
(Fade in).
It was on what I thought was my deathbed that I had a flashback and remembered how I had traveled to the future with Matt Smith and bought this marvelous game.
You see, these gangsta's were no ordinary ones. They were gamer gangsta's.
I called them on that agonizingly painful day and told them my story. They were bamboozled.
Still in disbelief, I gave them my beta code (the game was still in beta) that I had received from Matt Smith gave me which I for some reason had memorized.
(Fade Out).
(Return to present day).
And they released me. Now I'm here.
This is my sotry. Please no copipasterino dongerino guns-of-icarusino.

reviewText: GoIO is quite the unique game, with a mostly fantastic community, and an always active and open Dev team. the game is deceptivly simple at first, but as you play you realise how deep and teamwork oriented everything is. i also love that the game caters to pretty much every possible play style in a ship to ship combat game, want to rush in and ram things to splinters? you can do it, want to run in, pop a ballon or set some fires and run away to safety? check, want to play it safe and snipe from across the map, you can do that too. you can even just launch a bunch of mines and try to trick the enemy into flying into them. anything and everything can be effective as long as you have good teamwork, and with a surprisingly civil community thats not a problem.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This team based game with battle zeppelins, it's post-apocaliptic steapunk/dieselpunk based setting.

Guns of Icarus are a teamwork nor merely team based game, and I havent seen any game better at it thus far. You are 1 of 4 ship's crew members and your goal is to destroy enemy airships. You can't target other players, you can target only ships and various components on the ships. Teamwork is a requirement if you want to win or have fun (there is a lof of fun to be had with proper people). The community is generally very friendly.

Bringing a team of friends is helpfull, but it's not necesarry as you can easily find good teammemebers in matches.

It was October 5th, 1901, and I had just gotten my sonic screwdriver from the Doctor Who Warehouse sale. Of course, I was rich, being able to afford such a magnificent item. It had costed me a whole 90 cents. Compared to today, that was around a whopping 100,000 zen.
I was rolling down the streets, and the total gangsta's in the alley were hatin' me. Ya feel?
So anyway, I approached the bus stop, and with each step, I felt the growing presence of the gangsta's who were beginning to swarm around me.
I should've looked back.

(Fade in).
I awoke, thirsty, hungry, and most importantly, noticed that someone had taken my first edition Sonic Screwdriver that I had gotten.
I was chained up to the walls of what looked to be like someone's garage. I had little hope. No phone, no food, no water, and no screwdriver.
I spent over a month there. By that time I had begun eating my left foot, and drank the blood that spewed out of it.
Occasionally, a man dressed in all black came to give me some chicken scraps.
I ate the bones.
They kept me slave and I had worked for them for 3 months more. I was almost dead.
(Fade out).
(Fade in).
It was on what I thought was my deathbed that I had a flashback and remembered how I had traveled to the future with Matt Smith and bought this marvelous game.
You see, these gangsta's were no ordinary ones. They were gamer gangsta's.
I called them on that agonizingly painful day and told them my story. They were bamboozled.
Still in disbelief, I gave them my beta code (the game was still in beta) that I had received from Matt Smith gave me which I for some reason had memorized.
(Fade Out).
(Return to present day).
And they released me. Now I'm here.

reviewText: GoIO is quite the unique game, with a mostly fantastic community, and an always active and open Dev team. the game is deceptivly simple at first, but as you play you realise how deep and teamwork oriented everything is. i also love that the game caters to pretty much every possible play style in a ship to ship combat game, want to rush in and ram things to splinters? you can do it, want to run in, pop a ballon or set some fires and run away to safety? check, want to play it safe and snipe from across the map, you can do that too. you can even just launch a bunch of mines and try to trick the enemy into flying into them. anything and everything can be effective as long as you have good teamwork, and with a surprisingly civil community thats not a problem.

reviewText:
This team based game with battle zeppelins, it's post-apocaliptic steapunk/dieselpunk based setting.

Guns of Icarus are a teamwork nor merely team based game, and I havent seen any game better at it thus far. You are 1 of 4 ship's crew members and your goal is to destroy enemy airships. You can't target other players, you can target only ships and various components on the ships. Teamwork is a requirement if you want to win or have fun (there is a lof of fun to be had with proper people). The community is generally very friendly.

Bringing a team of friends is helpfull, but it's not necesarry as you can easily find good teammemebers in matches.

reviewText:
Airships battles in a steampunk setting and a focus on coordinated teamwork. Does that sound interesting? Well let me tell you more.

There are 3 character classes, pilot, gunner and engineer, each which a primary role. Respectively: steering the ship, manning the guns, and repairing damaged parts. Now, when you start playing a match, you can't switch classes anymore (for obvious balancing reasons), but fortunately you get the option to multitask. You can freely run around the ships while you fly and are not stuck doing the same thing every time. If there's no need for repairing, an engineer can for instance quickly man a gun. Each class gets to choose 3 skills or tools for its own specialization, and one for the other two types. For instance, when being an engineer, you can pick 3 engineer perks, one gunner perk and one pilot perk. That way you're never completely useless taking over another role briefly, something which I really like. Now let's talk about the ships, seeing as they're the stars of this game. Each vessel is customizable to a certain degree. There a 6 different types of ship you can choose from. They range from quick but frail to sturdy but sluggish and several variations in between. They're all layed out differently as well, forcing you to learn the pro's and cons and how to get around on each one if you want to get good at the game. This isn't just important for defensive purposes like knowing the best route around the ship to get to a damaged part, but also to know what to aim for as a gunner, and what to steer clear from as a pilot. The goldfish for instance has its heaviest gun on the front. So you have to either try and stay at its side or be able to decommission the main cannon to stay out of harm's way. That brings me to the ship customization. There are a fixed number of weapon slots on each ship, predetermined for heavy or lighter gun types. While you can't just put any heavy cannon randomly on your ship, you do get to choose between various different guns for each slot.

A fun setup for instance, is getting a lighter ship and having a heavy lumberjack cannon on the front, which does extra damage to balloons and also put some flamethrowers on the side. That way you can swoop in, cripple your enemy's vessel by forcing them into a descend, and then turn up above and around them and burn the ever living hell out of their ship. This will set their equipment on fire so any repairs are hampered, forcing them to keep plummeting and smash into the ground underneath! This is especially handy to take down the very sturdy but sluggish galleon type ship, as their main guns are on the lower sides and they would have a hard time aiming upwards at you while you burn them. It is well balanced however. This approach isn't going to be that effective when you take on more agile ships.

I do have some very minor gripes with the game. It tends to crash to desktop every so often. However, the loading times are incredibly short and there's even a quick re-join button on the main menu that gets you right back into the match. If you crash it might literally only take 30 seconds to get back to your crew. Another thing is that the spawning might get a little glitchy for a few seconds, graphically. I think it has to do with the way the game loads. I've had the odd ship part glitching out too, but nothing too terrible. Actually, I've encountered very few game-breaking bugs overall.

The developers also promised to keep adding more content in the future and up 'till now, they've definitely kept their promises. You can also often see them online in the regional chat in the main lobby, actively conversing with the players. Concluding: I definitely recommend this one!

reviewText:
I love this game. A lot. Probably as much as I loved Natural Selection, Dota, or Mount & Blade. (TF maybe too)

Rewarding, updated, good looking, and balanced. The community is great. The matchmaking is reasonably good, and there are great stats, achievements & visuals to unlock/purchase (clothing, paints/dyes themes none of which gives you advantage in game mechanics, so there is ZERO PAY TO WIN).
The difficulty and complexity scales from novice to pro nicely so there's almost always something new to learn, a trick or experience you haven't done before.

Short description:
Exciting team-based gameplay. Not like anything you have played before most likely.
Crew combat airships of various specialties/layouts in 2v2, 3v3 or 4v4 ships versus ships.
Each ship has a crew of at least 1 pilot and 3 ai crew, or up to 4 players per ship crew (including pilot).
Usually that means a driver, a gunner and some engineers who split their time repairing damage and shooting extra guns.
The learning curve for crew (non-driver) is pretty easy, the pilot is a bit more tricky (flying in 3 dimensions and leading your crew usually at the same time, often on voicecomm).

A match generally consists of a lobby (either deathmatch; first team to a certain number of kills, king of the hill, or cap the flag/KotH), where a map is voted on, and both teams' ship, crew, and weapons setups are organized.. before the timer ends and the match starts (plenty of time generally).
During a match you try put enemy ships in your weapons range/arc and knock out their components like guns, balloon, armor, or engines, with the hull under the armor being the finisher.

Each weapon, and ammo have their own thing they are mostly" used for
date: and a more strict effective range plus turning limit
recommended: so the pilot must work with the gunners to give the crew good lines of fire etc.\n\nNon-pilots also use spotting scopes to tag enemy ships with a bracket for easier identification at range. Ships can use cover of terrain and clouds to evade detection/damage. While piloting skills are often the most influential single factor in win:loss
hoursPlayed: a crew of really bad humans can contribute to a loss more than having ai crew sometimes
voteText: and a good human crew is ALWAYS better than the 'bots'.\n\nThe view from the open air deck of your ship is nice
helpfulPercent: and you as a crewperson are immune to enemy gun fire
votesHelpful: but you can fall off
votesTotal: which leads to a realistic fall-time and death with an immediate respawn onboard. Once familiar with the ship layouts this will rarely
votesFunny: if ever
commentsCount: happen
column16: and even if it does
column17: it isn't a match ender.\n\nAs a ship is damaged
column18: the guys with repair hammers go to work to get things repaired
column19: which is pretty fast paced and well done as a mechanic. They also do firefighting and buffing on ship components. The hull itself cannot be repaired during the match
column20: which is why ships want to try to keep their armor intact as much as possible to protect the hull/structure. And of course if you lose your balloon you fall out of the sky
column21:
no engines make you a sitting duck etc.

People are nice and will 'teach you the trade' "on the job" quickly.

9/10
Highly recommended if you like teamwork games."

reviewText:
This game is amazingly fun to play with friends. The only bad thing about this game is that there aren't enough people playing it, and that me and my friends have experienced a few server issues and random game shut downs.
But honestly the gameplay itself makes up for that. Because once you're flying through the skies and communicating with your friends, yelling who takes which gun and who is repairing what, where the ship is turning and where the enemies are going, it is an amazing and intense experience.
Teamwork is crucial to this game, so I recommend either playing it with people you can commucate with or establishing a chain of command.
Another thing to love about this game is how satisfying the weapons feel! It is very satisfying to fire the weapons and have whatever projectiles you sent of connect with the enemy, heck even the reload animations are cool. The game has great athmosphere and everything feels alive, it is definately worth a try.

reviewText:
Buy four copies, give them to everyone you know. I'm a huge steampunk fan and I can honestly say I've never seen a game with the scope of Guns of Icarus Online. That being said, when I first saw the game listed on steam I was more than hesitant to pick it up. The idea of being bound to an airship was an initial turn off for me and I didn't know what the community would be like. All the same, I decided to take the plunge and my only regret is not getting it sooner.

Guns is easily one of my favorite multiplayer games. You can learn everything you need to play the game in five minutes, though the game is challenging enough that mastery will take a great deal longer.  The three classes in the game are pilot, gunner and engineer. These three classes have a variety of strategies for players to utilize, as well as a ranking system to track progress.

I can't begin to recommend the game enough

reviewText:
YARRRR ME HEARTIES

This game is amazing and addictive... but what'd you expect from a steampunk-like airship combat simulator, tactically blowing your enemies to smithereens? The game's all about teamwork, enhancing and requiring a lot of contact between a ship's crew, which makes the game an amazing thing to play, and usually ends up being very socially cosy and enjoyable, and often gives you your daily healthy dose of rage. The community so far is great, too!

An important point to bring forward to this game is that in order to play correctly and efficiently, you WILL need a microphone. The developers have alternatives such as voice commands, which helps, but for the most fluent and efficient communications, one should use microphone communications. The microphone recording/playback quality in-game are very fast and good enough to understand each other clearly.

The game is well-populated and features an unique experience system through earning achievements. This encourages variety in your playstyle in order to discover what suits you and your crew most. Did I mention hats yet? Everybody likes hats. Especially if most of the cool hats and paint dyes are unlockable through gaining achievements anyway!

Apart from the unavoidable bugs every now and then, the game's graphics are neatly done and the UI is very accessible and easy to get the hang of. The music is repetitive but cool, and the gameplay is astonishing. The 3 different classes give the player an opportunity to play as they like. Extremely roughly said: for constant focus on dodging and tactically positioning the ship, as well as laying traps and ramming into others without being able to maintain the ship itself, choose Pilot. For routine maintaining the ship under heavy pressure, repairing and rebuilding, as well as shooting every now and then, go Engineer. For pure shooting with special ammo and helping out with repairs every now and then, take Gunner. There's usually room on a ship for 1 Pilot, 2 Engineers and 1 Gunner. At least, that is most likely the most beneficial option.

Once you go Guns of Icarus, ya can't stop, so get it now, I recommend it to everyone with a sense for action-packed fun, cooperation and enjoyment.

reviewText: For what this game is, it's incredibly balanced and has the perfect sized community. You'll find yourself traveling along slowly, but there will always be something for everyone on your crew to be doing productively. The strategy gets extremely deep with ship customization and you can easily struggle to keep up as a new player. Do not do pilot as one. Also, if you have lag you're doomed and your crew is going to yell at you. It happens. However, if you're a strategist fine with frustration coming mainly out of non-addiction and a limited amount of ship kills, this game is for you.

reviewText:
Guns of Icarus Online is an absolutely spectacular game, certainly worth the price (especially if you and three friends all pool your money and get the 4-pack). Given that ship crews are four people strong (captain, engineer and two gunners in my group) this works out well.

For an online-only game, and in absolute terms, the community is fantastic - never once have I encountered a rude player and novices actually get a chance to learn the game rather than be bullied out by the more-experienced players (looking at you, LoL).

Feature-wise, the game is very dependant on teamwork, no single ship is overpowered and there are many different weapon loadouts for each given ship, making spotting and target identification a must-have skill. Each player can take five items of equipment (one sailing tool, one engineering tool, one gunnery tool; plus two extras for their chosen class), which allows for even more customisation in fighting style. The levelling system is strange but it works - achievements count towards levels, with so many achievements being needed to level up. Crucially for an online-only game, there is absolutely no pay-to-win.

The game looks amazing, there's no doubt about that. Everything is beautifully rendered and designed. The soundtrack and in-game SFX are also incredible.

The only downside I can think of is that if the game lags, it can have a severe impact on the entire crew's effectiveness, especially if the Captain is the one with the lag issues.

reviewText: In Guns of Icarus Online, you can setup a squad of 4 players and drive a Steampunk airship into battle.  The graphics in this game are amazing and when you fly around in a pretty environment the game looks amazing.  There are 3 different classes.  The first one being the gunner, obviously shooting at the other ships.  There is more to the gunner than just blowing ammo into the other ships.  You have different turrets and types of ammo you can cycle through and you also have to calculate projectile drop and damage based on the velocity of the shot.  The next role being engineer, which you have to repair the engines and turrets.  The engineers also have to put out fires on the ship and keep all of the systems working.  The next role is the pilot.  The pilot has to manuever the ship and stay away from danger.  There are many obstacles in the map.  You also have to make sure all of the gunners have a clear shot at the enemy planes while at the same time avoiding dust clouds that damage your plane.  Overall the game is great and worth every penny.  I picked it up during the sale in which it was 75% off so it was only $3.74.  I would say it is still worth it at it's original price.  To succeed in this game, you must use teamwork and cooperation to take down other ships.\n\n10/10
